The '''disposable soma theory of aging''' states that organisms age due to an evolutionary trade-off between growth, reproduction, and [[DNA repair|DNA repair maintenance]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |authors=Kirkwood, T. | year = 1977 | title = Evolution of ageing | journal = Nature | volume = 270 | issue = | pages = 301–304 | doi=10.1038/270301a0| bibcode = 1977Natur.270..301K }}</ref> Formulated by [[Thomas Kirkwood]], the disposable soma theory explains that an organism only has a limited amount of resources or "soma" that it can allocate to its various [[cellular processes]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Gavrilov LA, Gavrilova NS | year = 2002 | title = Evolutionary theories of aging and longevity | journal = ScientificWorldJournal | volume = 7 | issue =2 | pages = 339–356 | doi=10.1100/tsw.2002.96}}</ref> Therefore, a greater investment in growth and reproduction would result in reduced investment in DNA repair maintenance, leading to increased [[Cell damage|cellular damage]], [[telomere#shortening|shortened telomeres]], accumulation of [[mutation#harmful mutations|mutations]], compromised [[stem cells]], and ultimately, [[senescence]]. Although many models, both animal and human, have appeared to support this theory, parts of it are still controversial. Specifically, while the [[evolutionary trade-off]] between [[Mechanistic target of rapamycin#Aging|growth and aging]] has been well established, the relationship between reproduction and aging is still without [[scientific consensus]], and the cellular mechanisms largely undiscovered.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal |authors=Blagosklonny, MV | year = 2010| title = Why the disposable soma theory cannot explain why women live longer and why we age | journal = Aging | volume = 2 | issue = 12 | pages = 884–887 | doi=10.18632/aging.100253}}</ref>
== Background and history ==
British biologist Thomas Kirkwood first proposed the disposable soma theory of aging in a 1977 [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']] review article.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> The theory was inspired by [[Leslie Orgel|Leslie Orgel's]] [[Error catastrophe|Error Catastrophe Theory of Aging]], which was published fourteen years earlier, in 1963. Orgel believed that the process of aging arose due to mutations acquired during the replication process, and Kirkwood developed the disposable soma theory in order to mediate Orgel's work with [[evolutionary genetics]].<ref name="ReferenceA" />
==Principles== The disposable soma theory of aging acts on the premise that there is a tradeoff in [[resource allocation]] between [[Maintenance of an organism|somatic maintenance]] and [[Parental investment|reproductive investment]]. Too low an investment in self-repair would be evolutionarily unsound, as the organism would likely die before reproductive age. However, too high an investment in self-repair would also be [[Fitness (biology)|evolutionarily unsound]] due to the fact that one's [[Survivorship curve|offspring would likely die before reproductive age]]. Therefore, there is a compromise and resources are partitioned accordingly. However, this compromise is thought to damage somatic repair systems, which can lead to [[DNA damage theory of aging|progressive cellular damage and senescence]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Drenos F, Kirkwood, TB | year = 2005| title = Modelling the disposable soma theory of ageing | journal = Mech Ageing Dev. | volume = 126 | issue = 1 | pages = 99–103| doi=10.1016/j.mad.2004.09.026}}</ref> Repair costs can be categorized into three groups: (1) the costs of increased [[Regeneration (biology)#Tissues|durability of nonrenewable parts]]; (2) the costs of maintenance involving [[Autophagy|cell renewal]], and (3) the costs of intracellular maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Kirkwood, TB, Rose MR | year = 1991| title = Evolution of senescence: late survival sacrificed for reproduction.| journal = Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci | volume = 332 | issue = 1262 | pages = 15–24| doi=10.1098/rstb.1991.0028}}</ref> In a nutshell, [[Antagonistic pleiotropy hypothesis|aging and decline is essentially a tradeoff]] for increased reproductive robustness in youth.
== Mechanisms == [[File:IGF-1Pathway.png|thumb|The [[IGF-1|IGF-1 pathway]], which represses [[FOXO]], thus preventing [[gene expression]] of longevity-inducing proteins.]]
=== Growth and somatic maintenance === {{main|Mechanistic target of rapamycin#Aging}} Much research has been done on the antagonistic effects of increased growth on lifespan. Specifically, the hormone [[insulin-like growth factor 1]] (IGF-1), binds to a cell receptor, leading to a [[phosphorylation cascade]]. This cascade results in kinases phosphorylating [[FOX proteins|forkhead transcription factor]] (FOXO), deactivating it. Deactivation of FOXO results in an inability to express genes involved in responding to [[oxidative stress |oxidative stress response]], such as [[antioxidants]], [[Chaperone (protein)|chaperones]], and [[heat-shock proteins]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=O'Neill BT, Lee KY, Klaus K, Softic S; et al. | year = 2016 | title = Insulin and IGF-1 receptors regulate FoxO-mediated signaling in muscle proteostasis | journal = J Clin Invest | volume = 126 | issue = 9 | pages = 3433-3346 | doi=10.1172/JCI86522| pmc = 5004956 }}</ref> Additionally, uptake of IGF-1 stimulates the [[Mechanistic target of rapamycin|mTOR]] pathway, which activates protein synthesis (and therefore growth) through upregulation of the translation-promoting [[P70-S6 Kinase 1|S6K1]], and also inhibits [[autophagy]], a process necessary for recycling of damaged cellular products.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Johnson SC, Rabinovitch PS, Kaeberlein M| year = 2013 | title = mTOR is a key modulator of ageing and age-related disease| journal = Nature | volume = 493 | issue = | pages = 338–345 | doi=10.1038/nature11861| bibcode = 2013Natur.493..338J| pmc = 3687363}}</ref> Decline of autophagy causes [[neurodegeneration]], [[protein aggregation]] and [[premature aging]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Komatsu M, Waguri S, Chiba T, Murata S; et al. | year = 2006 | title = Loss of autophagy in the central nervous system causes neurodegeneration in mice | journal = Nature | volume = 441 | issue = | pages = 880–884 | doi=10.1038/nature04723| bibcode = 2006Natur.441..880K }}</ref> Lastly, studies have also indicated that the mTOR pathway also alters [[immune responses]] and stimulates [[cyclin-dependent kinase]] (CDK) inhibitors such as [[p16]] and [[p21]]. This leads to alteration of the [[stem-cell niche]] and results in [[Stem cell theory of aging|stem cell exhaustion]], another theorized mechanism of aging.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Castilho RM1, Squarize CH, Chodosh LA, Williams BO; et al. | year = 2009| title = mTOR mediates Wnt-induced epidermal stem cell exhaustion and aging.| journal = Cell Stem Cell | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 279–289. | doi=10.1016/j.stem.2009.06.017}}</ref>
=== Reproduction and somatic maintenance=== The mechanism of why reproduction inhibits lifespan with regards to multicellular organisms is still unclear. Although many models do illustrate an inverse relationship, and the theory makes sense from an evolutionary perspective, [[Cell signaling|the cellular mechanisms]] have yet to be explored. However, with regards to [[cellular replication]], the progressive shortening of telomeres is a mechanism which [[Hayflick limit|limits the amount of generations of a single cell may undergo]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Shay JW, Wright WE | year = 2011 | title = Role of telomeres and telomerase in cancer | journal = Semin Cancer Biol. | volume = 21 | issue = 6 | pages = 349–353 | doi=10.1016/j.semcancer.2011.10.001}}</ref> Furthermore, in unicellular organisms like ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'', the formation of [[extrachromosomal rDNA circle]]s (ERCs) in mother cells (but not daughter cells) upon every subsequent division is an identifiable type of DNA damage that is associated with replication. These ERCs accumulate over time and eventually trigger replicative senescence and death of the mother cell.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Kaeberlein M, McVey M, Guarente L | year = 1999 | title = The SIR2/3/4 complex and SIR2 alone promote longevity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae by two different mechanisms| journal = Genes Dev. | volume = 13 | issue = 19| pages = 2570–2580}}</ref>
==Evidence==
===Growth and aging=== There is a large body of evidence indicating the negative effects of growth on longevity across many species. As a general rule, individuals of a smaller size generally live longer than larger individuals of the same species.
==== Animal models ==== In [[Dwarfism|dwarf]] models of [[Mus musculus|mice]], such Snell or Ames mice, mutations have arisen, either rendering them incapable of producing IGF-1 or unable to have adequate receptors for IGF-1 uptake. Furthermore, mice injected with growth hormone have been shown to have progressive weight loss, roughing of the coat, [[Scoliosis|curvature of the spine]], [[Hypertrophy|enlargement of the organs]], kidney lesions and [[Cancer|increased cancer risk]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Bartke A1, Brown-Borg H | year = 2004 | title = Life extension in the dwarf mouse | journal = Curr Top Dev Biol. | volume = 63 | issue = | pages = 189–225| doi=10.1016/j.semcancer.2011.10.001}}</ref> This effect is also seen in different breeds of [[dogs]], where smaller breeds of dogs typically live significantly longer compared to their larger counterparts. Selectively bred for their small size, smaller dog breeds like the [[Chihuahua (dog)|Chihuahua]] (average lifespan of 15–20 years) have the B/B genotype for the IGF-1 [[haplotype]], reducing the amount of IGF-1 produced. Conversely, large dogs like the [[Great Dane]] (average lifespan of 6–8 years) are [[homozygous]] for the IGF-1 I [[allele]], which increases the amount of IGF-1 production.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Sutter NB, Bustamante CD, Chase K, Gray MM | year = 2007| title =A Single IGF1 Allele Is a Major Determinant of Small Size in Dogs| journal = Science | volume = 316 | issue = 5821 | pages = 112–115 | doi=10.1126/science.1137045| bibcode =2007Sci...316..112S}}</ref>
====Human models==== Initially, it was believed that growth hormone actually prolonged lifespan due to a 1990 study that indicated that injection of [[growth hormone]] to men over 60 years of age appeared to reverse various [[biomarkers]] implicated in aging, such as [[Sarcopenia|decreased muscle mass]], bone density, skin thickness, and increased adipose tissue.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Rudman D1, Feller AG, Nagraj HS, Gergans GA; et al. | year = 1990| title =Effects of human growth hormone in men over 60 years old| journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 323 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–6 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199007053230101}}</ref> However, a 1999 study found that administering growth hormone also significantly increased [[mortality rate]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Takala J1, Ruokonen E, Webster NR, Nielsen MS, Zandstra DF, et al. | year = 1999| title = Increased mortality associated with growth hormone treatment in critically ill adults| journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 341 | issue = 11 | pages = 785–792 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199909093411102}}</ref> Recent [[Genome Sequencing|genomic studies]] have confirmed that the genes involved in growth hormone uptake and signaling are largely conserved across a plethora of species, such as yeast, nematodes, fruit flies, mice and humans.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Longo VD, Finch CE.| year = 2003| title =Evolutionary medicine: from dwarf model systems to healthy centenarians?| journal = Science | volume = 299 | issue = 5611 | pages = 1342–1346 | doi=10.1126/science.1077991}}</ref> These studies have also shown that individuals with [[Laron syndrome]], an [[autosomal recessive]] disorder resulting in dwarfism due to defects in growth hormone receptors, have increased lifespan. Additionally, these individuals have much lower [[Incidence (epidemiology)|incidences]] of age-related diseases such as [[type 2 diabetes]] and cancer.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Guevara-Aguirre J, Balasubramanian P, Guevara-Aguirre M, Wei M; et al. | year = 2011| title = Growth hormone receptor deficiency is associated with a major reduction in pro-aging signaling, cancer, and diabetes in humans | journal = Sci. Transl. Med. | volume = 3 | issue = 70 | pages = 70–83 | doi=10.1126/scitranslmed.3001845}}</ref> Lastly, human [[centenarians]] around the world are disproportionately of [[short stature]], and have low levels of IGF-1.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Govindaraju D, Atzmon G, Barzilai N. | year = 2015| title =Genetics, lifestyle and longevity: Lessons from centenarians.| journal = Appl Transl Genom. | volume = 4| issue = | pages = 23–32 | doi=10.1016/j.atg.2015.01.001}}</ref>
===Reproduction and aging=== Numerous studies have found that lifespan is inversely correlated with both the total amount of offspring birthed, as well as the age at which females first gives birth, also known as primiparity.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |authors=Descamps S, Boutin S, Berteaux D, Gaillard JM.| year = 2006| title =Best squirrels trade a long life for an early reproduction| journal = Proc Biol Sci | volume = 273| issue = 1599 | pages = 2369–2374 | doi= 10.1098/rspb.2006.3588}}</ref> Additionally, it has been found that [[Sexual reproduction|reproduction]] is a costly mechanism that alters the [[Fatty acid metabolism|metabolism of fat]]. [[Lipids]] invested in reproduction would be unable to be allocated to support mechanisms involved in somatic maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hansen M, Flatt T, Aguilaniu H.| year = 2013| title =Reproduction, fat metabolism, and life span: what is the connection?| journal = Cell Metab.| volume = 17| issue = 1 | pages = 10–19 | doi= 10.1016/j.cmet.2012.12.003}}</ref>
==== Animal models ====
The disposable soma theory has been consistent with the majority of animal models. It was found in numerous animal studies that [[castration]] or [[Genetic disorder|genetic deformities]] of [[Reproductive system|reproduction organs]] was [[correlated]] with increased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Drori D, Folman Y.| year = 1976| title =Environmental effects on longevity in the male rat: exercise, mating, castration and restricted feeding| journal = Exp Gerontol.| volume = 11| issue = 1 | pages = 25–32}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Flatt T| year = 2011| title =Survival costs of reproduction in ''Drosophila''.| journal = Exp Gerontol.| volume = 46| issue = 5 | pages = 369–375 | doi= 10.1016/j.exger.2010.10.008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hsin H, Kenyon C| year = 1999| title =Signals from the reproductive system regulate the lifespan of ''C. elegans''| journal =Nature| volume =399| issue = 6734 | pages = 362–366 | doi= 10.1038/20694| bibcode =1999Natur.399..362H}}</ref> Moreover, in [[red squirrels]], it was found that females with an early primiparity achieved the highest immediate and lifetime reproductive success. However, it was also found that these same individuals had a decreased median and maximum lifespan. Specifically squirrels who mated earlier had a 22.4% rate of mortality until two years of age compared to a 16.5% rate of mortality in late breeders. In addition, these squirrels had an average maximum lifespan of 1035 days compared to an average maximum lifespan of 1245 days for squirrels that bred later.<ref name="ReferenceB" />
In another study, researchers selectively bred [[Drosophila melanogaster|fruit flies]] over three years to develop two different [[strain (biology)|strain]]s, an early-reproducing strain and a late-reproducing strain. The late-reproducing line had a significantly longer lifespan than the early-reproducing line. Even more telling was that when the researchers introduced a mutation in the [[Ovarian|ovarian-associated]] gene ''ovoD1'', resulting in defective [[oogenesis]], the differences in lifespan between the two lines disappeared. The researchers in this case concluded that "aging has evolved primarily because of the damaging effects of reproduction earlier in life".<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Sgrò CM, Partridge L| year = 1999| title = A delayed wave of death from reproduction in Drosophila.| journal =Science| volume =286| issue =5449 | pages = 2521–2524 }}</ref>
Prominent aging researcher [[Steven N. Austad|Steven Austad]] also performed a large-scale [[ecological]] study on the [[coast]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in 1993. Austad isolated two [[opossum]] populations, one from the [[predator]]-infested mainland and one from the predator-absent nearby island of [[Sapelo]]. According to the disposable soma theory, a [[Genetic isolate|genetically isolated]] population subject to low environmentally-induced mortality would evolve delayed reproduction and aging. This is because without the pressure of predation, it would be evolutionarily advantageous to allocate more resources to somatic maintenance than reproduction, as early offspring mortality would be low. As predicted, even after controlling for predation, the isolated population had a longer lifespan, delayed primiparity, and reduced aging biomarkers such as tail [[collagen]] [[Cross linking|cross-linking]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Austad, SN| year = 1993| title =Retarded senescence in an insular population of Virginia opossums (''Didelphis virginiana'')| journal = Journal of Zoology| volume = 229| issue = 4 | pages = 695–708 | doi= 10.1111/j.1469-7998.1993.tb02665.x}}</ref>
====Human models ====
In general, only a few studies exist in human models. It was found that [[Eunuch|castrated men]] live longer than their [[fertile]] counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hamilton JB, Mestler GE| year = 1969| title =Mortality and survival: comparison of eunuchs with intact men and women in a mentally retarded population)| journal = J. Gerontol.| volume = 24| issue = 4 | pages = 395–411 }}</ref> Further studies found that in British women, primiparity was earliest in women who died early and latest in women who died at the oldest ages. Furthermore, increased number of children birthed was associated with a decreased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Westendorp RG, Kirkwood TB| year = 1998| title =Human longevity at the cost of reproductive success |journal = Nature| volume = 396| issue = 6713 | pages = 743–746 | doi= 10.1038/25519}}</ref> A final study found that female centenarians were more likely to have children in later life compared average, especially past the age of 40. The researchers discovered that 19.2% of female centenarians had their first child after the age of 40, compared to 5.5% of the rest of the female population.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Perls TT, Alpert L, Fretts RC| year = 1997| title =Middle-aged mothers live longer |journal = Nature| volume = 389| issue = 6647 | pages = 133 | doi= 10.1038/38148| bibcode = 1997Natur.389..133P}}</ref>
=== Relationship between cell damage and aging=== {{main|Free radical theory}}{{main|DNA damage theory of aging}} [[File:Naked Mole Rat Eating.jpg|thumb|The [[naked mole rat]] has a [[naked mole rat#Longevity|disproportionately long life of 30 years]] through efficient cellular repair mechanisms.]] There are numerous studies that support cellular damage, often due to a lack of somatic maintenance mechanisms, as a primary determinant for aging, and these studies have given rise to the [[free radical theory of aging]] and the [[DNA damage theory of aging]]. One study found that the cells of short-living rodents ''[[in vitro]]'' show much greater [[mutation]] rates and a general lack of genome surveillance compared to human cells and are far more susceptible to [[oxidative stress]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Lorenzini A, Stamato T, Sell C. | year = 2011| title = The disposable soma theory revisited: time as a resource in the theories of aging | journal = Cell Cycle| volume = 10 | issue = 22 | pages = 3853–3856 | doi=10.4161/cc.10.22.18302}}</ref> Other studies have been conducted on the [[naked mole rat]], a rodent species with remarkable longevity (30 years), capable of outliving the [[brown rat]] (3 years) by [[Fold (higher-order function)|ten-fold]]. Additionally, almost no incidence cancer has ever been detected in naked mole rats. Nearly all of the differences found between these two organisms, which are otherwise rather genetically similar, was in somatic maintenance. Naked mole rats were found to have higher levels of [[superoxide dismutase]], a [[reactive oxygen species]] clearing [[antioxidant]]. In addition, naked mole rats had higher levels of [[base excision repair]], DNA damage response signaling, [[Homologous recombination|homologous recombination repair]], [[mismatch repair]], [[nucleotide excision repair]], and [[non-homologous end joining]]. In fact, many of these processes were near or exceeded human levels. Proteins from naked mole rats were also more resistant to [[oxidation]], [[misfolding]], [[ubiquitination]], and had increased [[Translation|translational fidelity]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Azpurua J, Ke Z, Chen IX, Zhang Q, Ermolenko DN; et al. | year = 2013| title = Naked mole-rat has increased translational fidelity compared with the mouse, as well as a unique 28S ribosomal RNA cleavage | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A| volume = 110 | issue = 43 | pages =17350–17355 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1313473110| bibcode =2013PNAS..11017350A}}</ref>
Further studies have been conducted on patients with [[Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome]] (HGPS), a condition that leads to premature aging. Patients with HGPS typically age about seven times faster than average and usually succumb to the disease in their early teens. Patients with HGPS have cellular defects, specifically in the [[Lamin A protein|lamin proteins]], which regulate the organization of the [[Nuclear lamina|lamina]] and [[nuclear envelope]] for [[mitosis]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Pollex RL1, Hegele RA | year = 2004| title = Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome | journal = Clin. Genet.| volume = 66| issue = 5 | pages =375–381 | doi=10.1111/j.1399-0004.2004.00315.x}}</ref>
Lastly, as mentioned previously, it has been found that the suppression of autophagy is associated with reduced lifespan, while stimulation is associated with extended lifespan. Activated in times of [[caloric restriction]], autophagy is a process that prevents cellular damage through clearance and [[recycling]] of damaged proteins and [[organelles]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Glick D1, Barth S, Macleod KF. | year = 2010| title = Autophagy: cellular and molecular mechanisms| journal = J. Pathol. | volume = 221 | issue = 1 | pages =3–12| doi=10.1002/path.2697}}</ref>
== Criticism== One of the main weaknesses of the disposable soma theory is that it does not postulate any specific cellular mechanisms to which an organism shifts energy to somatic repair over reproduction. Instead, it only offers an [[Evolution|evolutionary perspective]] on why aging may occur due to reproduction. Therefore, parts of it are rather limited outside of the field of [[evolutionary biology]].<ref name="ReferenceC" />
===Caloric restriction=== {{main|Calorie restriction#Sirtuin-mediated mechanism}} [[File:Soma Disposable.png|thumb|Schematic showing the reallocation of energy investment towards [[DNA repair|self-repair]] during [[caloric restriction]].]] Critics have pointed out the supposed [[Inconsistency|inconsistencies]] of the disposable soma theory due to the observed effects of caloric restriction, which is correlated with increased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Blagosklonny, MV| year = 2010| title = Solving puzzles of aging: From disposable soma to signal-transduction pathways| journal = Russ J Gen Chem. | volume = 80 | issue = | pages =1407}}</ref> Although it activates autophagy, according to classical disposable soma principles, with less [[Caloric|caloric intake]], there would less total energy to be distributed towards somatic maintenance, and decreased lifespan would be observed (or at least the positive autophagic effects would be balanced out). However, Kirkwood, alongside his collaborator Darryl P. Shanley, assert that caloric restriction triggers an adaptive mechanism which causes the organism to shift a higher proportion of resources to somatic maintenance, away from reproduction.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Shanley DP, Kirkwood TB.| year = 2000| title = Calorie restriction and aging: a life-history analysis.| journal = Evolution | volume = 54 | issue =3 | pages =1407}}</ref> This theory is supported by multiple studies, which show that caloric restriction typically results in [[Sterility (physiology)|impaired fertility]], but leave an otherwise healthy organism.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Holliday R.| year = 2000| title = Food, reproduction and longevity: is the extended lifespan of calorie-restricted animals an evolutionary adaptation?| journal = BioEssays | volume = 10 | issue =4 | pages =125–127|doi=10.1002/bies.950100408}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Masoro EJ, Austad SN.| year = 1996| title = The evolution of the antiaging action of dietary restriction: a hypothesis.| journal = J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci | volume = 51 | issue =6 | pages =387–391}}</ref> Evolutionarily, an organism would want to delay reproduction to when resources were more plentiful. During a resource-barren period, it would evolutionarily unwise to invest resources in progeny that would be unlikely to survive in [[famine]]. Mechanistically, the [[Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide|NAD]]-dependent [[Deacetylate|deacetylase]] [[Sirtuin 1]] (SIRT-1) is upregulated during low-nutrient periods. SIRT-1 increases [[insulin sensitivity]], decreases the amount of [[inflammatory cytokine]]s, stimulates autophagy, and activates FOXO, the aforementioned protein involved in activating stress response genes. SIRT-1 is also found to result in decreased fertility.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Cantó C, Auwerx J.| year = 2009| title = Caloric restriction, SIRT1 and longevity.| journal =Trends Endocrinol Metab| volume = 20 | issue =7 | pages =325–331|doi=10.1016/j.tem.2009.03.008}}</ref>
In additional to differential [[wikt:partitioning|partitioning]] of energy allocation during caloric restriction, less caloric intake would result in less metabolic waste in the forms of [[free radicals]] like [[hydrogen peroxide]], [[superoxide]] and [[hydroxyl radicals]], which damage important cellular components, particularly [[mitochondria]]. Elevated levels of free radicals in mice has been correlated with neurodegeneration, [[Myocardial|myocardial injury]], [[Anemia|severe anemia]], and premature death.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Pérez VI, Bokov A, Van Remmen H, Mele J; et al.| year = 2009| title = Is the oxidative stress theory of aging dead?| journal =Biochim Biophys Acta| volume = 1790 | issue =10 | pages =1005–1014|doi=10.1016/j.bbagen.2009.06.003}}</ref>
===The Grandmother hypothesis=== {{main|Menopause#Evolutionary rationale}} Another primary criticism of the disposable soma theory is that it fails to account for why women tend to live longer than their male counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Ginter E, Simko V | year = 2013| title = Women live longer than men| journal = Bratisl Lek Listy. | volume = 114 | issue = 2 | pages =45–49}}</ref> Afterall, females invest significantly more resources into reproduction and according to the classical disposable soma principles, this would compromise energy diverted to somatic maintenance. However, this can be reconciled with the [[grandmother hypothesis]]. The Grandmother Hypothesis states that [[menopause]] comes about into older women in order to restrict the time of reproduction as a protective mechanism. This would allow women to live longer and increase the amount of care they could provide to their [[grandchildren]], increasing their evolutionary fitness.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hawkes K | year = 2003| title = Grandmothers and the evolution of human longevity| journal = Am. J. Hum. Biol.| volume =15 | issue =3 | pages =380–400| doi= 10.1002/ajhb.10156}}</ref> And so, although women do invest a greater proportion of resources into reproduction during their [[Age and female fertility|fertile years]], their overall reproductive period is significantly shorter than men, who are able of reproduction during and even beyond [[middle age]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Vinicius L, Mace R, Migliano A| year = 2014| title = Variation in Male Reproductive Longevity across Traditional Societies| journal = PLoS One| volume =9 | issue =11 | pages =e112236| doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0112236| bibcode =2014PLoSO...9k2236V}}</ref> Additionally, males invest more resources into growth, and have significantly higher levels of IGF-1 compared to females, which is correlated with decreased lifespan. Other variables such as increased [[Testosterone|testosterone levels]] in males are not accounted for. Increased testosterone is often associated with reckless behaviour, which may lead to a high accidental death rate.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Celec P, Ostatníková D, Hodosy J. | year = 2015| title = On the effects of testosterone on brain behavioral functions| journal = Front. Neurosci.| volume =9 | issue = | pages =12| doi=10.3389/fnins.2015.00012}}</ref>
=== Contradicting models === A few [[Contradiction|contradicting]] animal models weaken the validity of the disposable soma theory. This includes studies done on the aforementioned naked mole rats. In these studies, it was found that reproductive naked mole rats actually show significantly increased lifespans compared to non-reproductive individuals, which contradicts the principles of diposable soma. However, although these naked mole rats are [[mammalian]], they are highly [[atypical]] in terms of aging studies and may not serve as the best model for humans. For example, naked mole rats have a disproportionately high longevity quotient and live in [[Eusociality|eusocial societies]], where breeding is usually designated to a [[Eusociality#In mammals|queen]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Dammann P, Burda H | year = 2006| title =Sexual activity and reproduction delay ageing in a mammal.| journal = Curr. Biol.| volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 117–118 | doi=10.1016/j.cub.2006.02.012}}</ref>
=== Sex biases and environment === The disposable soma theory is tested disproportionately on female organisms for the relationship between reproduction and aging, as [[Parental investment#Females as the more investing sex|females carry a greater burden in reproduction]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hammers M, Richardson DS, Burke T, Komdeur J. | year = 2013| title = The impact of reproductive investment and early-life environmental conditions on senescence: support for the disposable soma hypothesis.| journal = J Evol Biol | volume = 26| issue = 9 | pages = 1999–2007| doi=10.1111/jeb.12204}}</ref> Additionally, for the relationship between growth and aging, studies are disproportionately conducted on males, to minimize the [[Estrogen|hormonal fluctuations]] that occur with [[Menstrual cycle|menstrual cycling]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Wu JJ, Liu J, Chen EB, Wang JJ; et al. | year = 2013| title = Increased mammalian lifespan and a segmental and tissue-specific slowing of aging after genetic reduction of mTOR expression| journal = Cell Rep. | volume = 4| issue = 5 | pages = 913–920| doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2013.07.030}}</ref> Lastly, [[aging#Biological basis|genetic]] and [[Gene–environment interaction|environmental factors]], rather than reproductive patterns, may explain the variations in human lifespan. For example, studies have shown that [[Poverty|poorer individuals]], to whom nutritious food and [[medical care]] is less accessible, typically have higher birth rates and earlier primiparity.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Murray, S. | year = 2006| title = Poverty and health| journal = CMAJ | volume = 174| issue = 7 | pages = 923| doi=10.1503/cmaj.060235}}</ref>

[[File:Snowytreecricket.JPG|thumb|The tree cricket ''Oecanthus fultoni'']]'''Dolbear's law''' states the relationship between the air [[temperature]] and the rate at which [[Cricket (insect)|crickets]] chirp.<ref name=frings57/><ref name=frings62/> It was formulated by [[Amos Dolbear]] and published in 1897 in an article called "The Cricket as a Thermometer".<ref name=dolbear>{{cite journal |last1=Dolbear |first1=Amos |year=1897 |title=The cricket as a thermometer |journal=The American Naturalist |volume=31 |pages=970–971 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jqco0ttVn0gC&lpg=PA970&ots=jVb2ir2UK1&dq=%22The%20Cricket%20as%20a%20Thermometer%22&pg=PA970#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Cricket%20as%20a%20Thermometer%22&f=false|accessdate=27 November 2012 |doi=10.1086/276739}}</ref> Dolbear's observations on the relation between chirp rate and temperature were preceded by an 1881 report by Margarette W. Brooks,<ref group="n">According to Frings and Frings, this is: Margarette W. Brooks, "Influence of temperature on the chirp of the cricket", ''Popular Science Monthly'' 20 (1881), p. 268; citing "W.G.B.", a writer whom Brooks does not further identify. <!-- However, this report does not seem to appear anywhere within vol 20 of this magazine; see https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Popular_Science_Monthly/Volume_20 --></ref> although this paper went unnoticed until after Dolbear's publication.<ref name=frings62/>
Dolbear did not specify the species of cricket which he observed, although subsequent researchers assumed it to be the snowy tree cricket, "''Oecanthus niveus''."<ref name=frings57>{{cite journal |last1=Frings |first1=Hubert |last2=Frings |first2=Mable |year=1957 |title=The effects of temperature on chirp-rate of male cone-headed grasshoppers, Neoconocephalus ensiger |journal=Journal of Experimental Zoology |volume=134 |issue=3 |pages=411–425 |doi=10.1002/jez.1401340302 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jez.1401340302/abstract |accessdate=27 November 2012}}</ref> <ref name=frings62>{{cite journal |last1=Frings |first1=Hubert |last2=Frings |first2=Mable |year=1962 |title=Effects of temperature on the ordinary song of the common meadow grasshopper, Orchelimum vulgare (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae) |journal=Journal of Experimental Zoology |volume=151 |issue=1 |pages=33–51 |doi=10.1002/jez.1401510104 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jez.1401510104/abstract |accessdate=27 November 2012}}</ref><!-- Yes, this really is "Mable", not "Mabel". --> However, the snowy tree cricket was misidentified as ''O. niveus'' in early reports and the correct scientific name for this species is ''[[Oecanthus fultoni]]''.<ref name=walker62> {{cite journal |last1=Walker |first1=Thomas J. |year=1962 |title=The Taxonomy and Calling Songs of United States Tree Crickets (Orthoptera: Gryllidae: Oecaiithinae). I. The Genus ''Neoxabea'' and the ''niveus'' and ''varicornis'' Groups of the Genus ''Oecanthus'' |journal=Annals of the Entomological Society of America |volume=55 |issue=3 |pages=303–322 |publisher=Entomological Society of America |url=http://entnemdept.ifas.ufl.edu/Walker/buzz/s576lw62.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2012}}</ref>
The chirping of the more common [[field cricket]]s is not as reliably correlated to temperature—their chirping rate varies depending on other factors such as age and mating success. In many cases, though, the Dolbear's formula is a close enough approximation for field crickets, too.
Dolbear expressed the relationship as the following formula which provides a way to estimate the temperature ''T<sub>F</sub>'' in degrees Fahrenheit from the number of chirps per minute ''N<sub>60</sub>'':
<math>T_F = 50 + \left ( \frac{N_{60}-40}{4} \right ).</math>
This formula is accurate to within a degree or so when applied to the chirping of the [[field cricket]].
Counting can be sped up by simplifying the formula and counting the number of chirps produced in 15 seconds (''<math>N_{15}</math>''):
<math>\,T_F = 40 + N_{15}</math>
Reformulated to give the temperature in degrees Celsius (°C), it is:
<math>T_C = 10 + \left ( \frac{N_{60}-40}{7} \right ).</math>
A shortcut method for degrees Celsius is to count the number of chirps in 8 seconds (''<math>N_{8}</math>'') and add 5 (This is fairly accurate between 5 and 30°C):
<math>\,T_C = 5 + N_{8}</math>
The above formulae are expressed in terms of integers to make them easier to remember—they are not intended to be exact.
==In popular culture== This formula was referenced in an episode (Season 3, Episode 2, "[[The Jiminy Conjecture]]") of the American TV sitcom ''[[List of The Big Bang Theory episodes#The Jiminy Conjecture|The Big Bang Theory]]'' (although Sheldon referred to Amos Dolbear as Emile Dolbear and gave the year of publication as 1890). It is also referenced in two episodes ("[[Highs and Lows (QI episode)|Highs and Lows]]", "[[Jungles (QI episode)|Jungles]]") of the British comedy show [[QI]].

"'''Drinking the Kool-Aid'''" is an expression commonly used in the United States that refers to a person who believes in a possibly doomed or dangerous idea because of perceived potential high rewards. The phrase often carries a negative connotation. It can also be used ironically or humorously to refer to accepting an idea or changing a preference due to popularity, peer pressure, or persuasion. In recent years it has evolved further to mean extreme dedication to a cause or purpose, so extreme that one would "Drink the Kool-Aid" and die for the cause.{{fact|date=June 2018}}
The phrase derives from the November 1978 [[Jonestown#Deaths in Jonestown|Jonestown deaths]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Higgins |first=Chris |title=Stop Saying 'Drink the Kool-Aid'|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2012/11/stop-saying-drink-the-kool-aid/264957/|work=The Atlantic|accessdate=July 22, 2013|date=8 November 2012}} *{{Cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6353579 |title='Jonestown': Portrait of a Disturbed Cult Leader |work=Day to Day |date=October 20, 2006 |deadurl=no |accessdate=September 4, 2014}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.wordspy.com/words/drinktheKool-Aid.asp |title=Wordspy article on the expression "Drink the Kool-Aid," October 27, 1998 |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |author=Paul McFedries |date=1998-10-27 |publisher=Logophilia Limited, www.wordspy.com}}</ref> in which over 900 members of the [[Peoples Temple]] died by drinking a powdered drink mix [[Lacing (drugs)|laced]] with [[cyanide]]. Most voluntarily committed [[suicide]] while the rest were killed by forced ingestion of the poison.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hall|first1=John R.|title=Gone from the Promised Land: Jonestown in American Cultural History|date=1987|publisher=Transaction Publishers|isbn=9780887388019|page=282|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D8MCb1xqqo8C&pg=PA282|language=en}}</ref> The powdered drink mix used might not have been [[Kool-Aid]] but could have been the competing brand [[Flavor Aid]]. However this is disputed as the commune had both among their supplies. <ref>{{Cite news |title=Cult's survivors sought in jungle |newspaper=The Ledger |location=Lakeland, Florida |date=November 21, 1978 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zY4sAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9foDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6704,6145800 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}} *{{cite news| url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/347396/Jonestown-The-Life-and-Death-of-Peoples-Temple/overview | work=The New York Times | first=Stephen | last=Holden |title=Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple}}</ref>
==Background== {{main|Jonestown#Deaths in Jonestown}} On November 18, 1978, Jones ordered that the members of [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Leo Ryan]]'s party be killed after several defectors chose to leave with the party. Residents of the commune later committed suicide by drinking a flavored beverage laced with [[potassium cyanide]]; some were forced to drink it, some (such as small children) drank it unknowingly.<ref>''[[Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple]]''</ref> Roughly 918 people died.
Descriptions of the event often refer to the beverage not as [[Kool-Aid]] but as Flavor Aid,<ref name="Zorn">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.chicagotribune.com/news_columnists_ezorn/2008/11/have-you-drunk-the-kool-aid-kool-aid.html|title=''Change of Subject,'' "Have you drunk the 'Kool Aid' Kool Aid |accessdate=2009-08-27 |author=Eric Zorn |date=2008-11-18 |publisher=Chicago Tribune, www.chicagotribune.com}}</ref> a less-expensive product reportedly found at the site.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Charles A. |last=Krause |title=Jonestown Is an Eerie Ghost Town Now |newspaper=Washington Post|date=Dec 17, 1978|quote=Along the muddy path that served as a sidewalk for much of the commune, other reminders of the life and death that were Jonestown lie half buried in the fertile soil. A pair of woman's eyeglasses, a towel, a pair of shorts, packets of unopened Flavor-Aid lie scattered about waiting for the final cleanup that may one day return Jonestown to the tidy, if overcrowded, little community it once was.}}</ref> [[Kraft Foods]], the maker of Kool-Aid, has stated the same.<ref>*{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/92/debunk.html |title=Don't Drink the Grape-Flavored Sugar Water... |accessdate=2009-08-27 | author=Kihn, Martin|date=2007-12-19 |publisher=Fast Company|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050407051630/http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/92/debunk.html|archivedate=7 April 2005}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.poynter.org/column.asp?id=2&aid=54353 |title=''Al's Morning Meeting'', "Thursday Edition: Clearing Kool-Aid's Name" |accessdate=2009-08-27 | author=Al Thomkins |date=2003-11-13 |publisher= The Poynter Institute| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031204102604/http://www.poynter.org/column.asp?id=2&aid=54353|archivedate=4 December 2003}}</ref> Implied by this accounting of events is that the reference to the Kool-Aid brand owes exclusively to its being better-known among Americans. Others are less categorical.<ref name="Zorn"/> Both brands are known to have been among the commune's supplies: Film footage shot inside the compound prior to the events of November shows Jones opening a large chest in which boxes of both Flavor Aid and Kool-Aid are visible.<ref>{{cite video |people= Nelson, Stanley|year= 2006|title= Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZjfWuTHe0M&feature=fvsr#t=9m51s |format= |medium= DVD|language= |trans_title= |publisher= PBS Home Video|location= Hollywood, California|archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate= |time= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> Criminal investigators testifying at the Jonestown inquest spoke of finding packets of "cool aid" (''[[sic]]''), and eyewitnesses to the incident are also recorded as speaking of "cool aid" or "Cool Aid."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jonestown.sdsu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/GuyanaInquest.pdf |title=Guyana inquest |accessdate=}}</ref> It is unclear whether they intended to refer to the actual Kool-Aid–brand drink or were [[Genericized trademark|using the name in a generic sense]] that might refer to any powdered flavored beverage.
Given that both were available and are functionally very similar, it is hard to distinguish whether just one or both brands were used. The group had engaged in many "dry runs" using unpoisoned drink.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Utopian nightmare. Jonestown: What did we learn? |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=8 November 1998 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1998/11/08/NEWS4041.dtl |accessdate=2015-12-16 | first=Larry D. | last=Hatfield}}</ref>
==Use== In December 1978, Rev. Dr. [[William Sloane Coffin]] told a convention of the American unit of Pax Christi that American planning for nuclear war and preparations for civil defense was "the Kool-Aid drill without the cyanide."<ref>Hyer, Marjorie. Pax Christi Group Opposes SALT II. 9 December 1978. Washington Post.</ref>
According to academician Rebecca Moore, early analogies to Jonestown and Kool-Aid were based around death and suicide, not blind obedience.<ref name="moore">[http://jonestown.sdsu.edu/?page_id=16584 Drinking the Kool-Aid: The Cultural Transformation of a Tragedy], Rebecca Moore, American Academy of Religion/ Western Region, St. Mary’s College of California, 26 March 2002</ref> The earliest such example she found, via a [[Lexis-Nexis]] search, was a 1982 statement from [[Lane Kirkland]], then head of the [[AFL-CIO]], which described [[Ronald Reagan]]'s policies as "Jonestown economics," which "administers Kool-Aid to the poor, the deprived and the unemployed."<ref name="moore" />
In 1984, a Reagan administration appointee, Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., chairman of the [[United States Commission on Civil Rights]], was quoted as criticizing civil rights leaders [[Jesse Jackson]], [[Vernon Jordan Jr.]], and [[Benjamin Hooks]] by making an analogy between allegiance to "the black leadership" and blind obedience to the Jonestown leaders: "We refuse to be led into another political Jonestown as we were led during the Presidential campaign. No more Kool-Aid, Jesse, Vernon and Ben. We want to be free."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/20/us/criticism-of-black-leaders.html |title=Criticism of Black Leaders |newspaper=The New York Times |date=November 20, 1984 |accessdate=March 4, 2012}}</ref>
In 1989, Jack Solerwitz, a lawyer for many of the air traffic controllers who lost their jobs in the 1981 [[Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization (1968)|PATCO]] strike, explained his dedication to their cause in spite of the substantial personal financial losses he incurred by saying: "I was the only lawyer who kept the doors open for them, and I thought I'd get a medal for it... Instead, I was the one who drank the Kool-Aid."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/20/us/law-bar-lawyer-for-striking-air-traffic-controllers-won-back-60-jobs-but.html |title=LAW: AT THE BAR; Lawyer for striking air traffic controllers won back 60 jobs but suffered personal loss |first=David |last=Margolick |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 20, 1989 |accessdate=March 4, 2012}}</ref>
The widespread use of the phrase with its current meaning may have begun in the late 1990s. In some cases it began to take on a neutral or even positive light, implying simply great enthusiasm. In 1998, the dictionary website logophilia.com defined the phrase thus: "To become a firm believer in something; to accept an argument or philosophy whole-heartedly."<ref name="moore" />
The phrase has been used in the business and technology worlds to mean fervent devotion to a certain company or technology. A 2000 ''[[The New York Times]]'' article about the end of the [[dot-com bubble]] noted, "The saying around San Francisco Web shops these days, as companies run out of money, is 'Just keep drinking the Kool-Aid,' a tasteless reference to the Jonestown massacre."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/29/opinion/the-shadow-in-silicon-valley.html |title=The Shadow in Silicon Valley |first=Rodes |last=Fishburne |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 29, 2000 |accessdate=}}</ref>
The phrase or metaphor has also often been used in a political context, usually with a negative implication. In 2002, [[Arianna Huffington]] used the phrase "pass the Kool-Aid, pardner" in a column about an economic forum hosted by President [[George W. Bush]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://dir.salon.com/story/news/col/huff/2002/08/16/waco/index.html |title=Wacko in Waco |author=Arianna Huffington |publisher=Salon.com |date=August 16, 2002 |accessdate=August 16, 2011}}</ref> Later, commentators [[Michelangelo Signorile]] and [[Bill O'Reilly (commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] have used the term to describe those whom they perceive as following certain ideologies blindly.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2005/09/09/feeling-sorry-for-oreilly/ | work=Fox News | title=Feeling Sorry for O'Reilly | date=2005-09-09|accessdate=February 5, 2015}}</ref> In a 2009 speech, ''[[Newsweek]]'' editor [[Jon Meacham]] stressed his political independence by saying, "I did not drink the [[Barack Obama|Obama]] Kool-Aid last year."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.vcstar.com/news/2009/apr/01/newsweek-editor-addresses-reagan-forum/ |title=Newsweek editor addresses Reagan Forum |first=Jake |last=Finch |newspaper=Ventura County Star |date=April 1, 2009 |accessdate=}}</ref>
In 2011, columnist [[Meghan Daum]] wrote that the phrase had become "one of the nation's most popular idiomatic trends," while bemoaning its rise in popularity, calling its usage "grotesque, even offensive." She cited, among others, usages by [[Starbucks]] CEO [[Howard Schultz]], who said that he "drank the Kool-Aid as much as anyone else about Obama," and ''[[Us Weekly]]'' magazine, which reported during the short marriage of [[Kim Kardashian]] and [[Kris Humphries]] that "Kris is not drinking the Kardashian Kool-Aid."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/commentary/la-oe-daum-koolaid-20111117,0,347333.column |title=Don't 'drink the Kool-Aid' |first=Meghan |last=Daum |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=November 17, 2011 |accessdate=}}</ref>
In February 2012, "Drinking the Kool-Aid" won first place in an online poll by ''[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]'' Magazine as "the single most annoying example of [[business jargon]]."<ref> [https://www.forbes.com/special-report/2012/annoying-business-jargons-12.html Jargon Madness], ''Forbes,'' January 25, 2012.</ref>
==See also== *[[Red pill and blue pill|Blue pill]] *[[Irrationality]] *[[Skepticism]]

We should stop saying it immediately| work=PostEverything | publisher=[[The Washington Post]] | first=James D. |last=Richardson | date=November 18, 2014 | access-date=July 5, 2017 }}

[[File:Emmert experiment.jpg|thumb|Emmert's perceptual experiment]] The '''Emmert experiment''' is a perceptual experiment by psychologist [[Emil Emmert]] (1844–1911). The experiment is based on the size constancy.
==Principles== Besides localization and recognition, there is another function of our sensory system: the size of the objects remain constant in spite of the changes of the image perceived our retina. Thanks to evolution we experience the objects as they really are and not as our eyes perceives them. We usually perceive object as being relatively constant, irrespective of the light conditions, our point of view or the distance between the object and us.
Our cars do not seem to be bigger even if we are approaching them, their form do not become more distorted, their colour does not change even if we apply artificial lighting. This phenomenon is called perceptual constancy.
The most studied constancy is the size constancy, or the phenomenon as when we perceive the constant size of the objects independently to their distance. As an object moves farther away, their perceived size usually does not decrease as we are looking at them.
==Example== Hold a coin in front of you, 30 centimeters away from you and then move it at arm’s length. Does the coin seem smaller? Obviously not, but the size of the retinal image of the coin is two times bigger than the retinal image of the coin when it was 30 centimeters away.
In the Emmert experiment, we keep a book in front of us within normal reading distance, with good light conditions. Fixate our look into the middle of the object for 1 minute and look to a wall further away. We can see the post-images of the two circles that seem to be bigger than the stimulus. Now let’s look at a paper close to our eyes. The post-image is smaller than the stimulus. If the post-image disappears it can be restored by blinking.
== References ==
* Bonnet, C., & Pouthas, V. (1972). Apparent size and duration of a movement after-effect: The [[Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology]] * Dwyer, J., Ashton, R., & Broerse, J. (1990). Emmert's law in the Ames room: Perception * Epstein W, Park J, Casey A. (1961) The current status of the size-distance hypotheses. [[Psychological Bulletin]], 58: 491-514. * Makosky, V. P., Whittemore, L. G., & Rogers, A. M. (1987). Activities handbook for the teaching of psychology * Fisher, G. H. (1968). Illusions and Size-Constancy: [[American Journal of Psychology]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Evan Roth | image = Evan Roth head shot.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Evan Andrew Roth | birth_date = March 5, 1978{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} | birth_place = [[Okemos]], [[Michigan]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[interactive art]], [[Computer programming|programming]], [[generative art]], [[LED Throwies]], [[digital art]], [[net art]] | training = [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] and [[Parsons The New School for Design]] | movement = | works = [[Graffiti Research Lab]], [[Free Art and Technology Lab]], [[EyeWriter]] | patrons = | awards = }} '''Evan Roth''' (born 1978) is a US artist who applies a hacker philosophy to an art practice that visualizes transient moments in public space, online and in popular culture.<ref>http://www.evan-roth.com/about/</ref> In 2012, he was awarded a Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt [[National Design Award]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Kurutz | first = Steven | title = Evan Roth, an Award-Winning Man of Many Tags | pages = | publisher = [[The New York Times]] | date = 2012-05-02 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/03/garden/evan-roth-an-award-winning-designer-and-artist.html | accessdate = 2012-11-19 }} </ref>
==Biography==
Evan Roth received a degree in architecture from [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] and a MFA from the Communication, Design and Technology school at [[Parsons The New School for Design]], where he graduated as class valedictorian.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} During his time at Parsons, he developed several projects, including Graffiti Taxonomy, Typographic Illustration, Explicit Content Only and Graffiti Analysis, his thesis project. Roth was named one of the ten most interesting recent graduates of 2006.<ref>"Head of the Class", ''RES'', 9(2):52,56</ref>
After graduating Roth worked at the [[Eyebeam Atelier|Eyebeam]] OpenLab, an open source creative technology lab for the public domain as a Research and Development Fellow from 2005–2006 and a Senior Fellow from 2006-2007. Roth's work with graffiti, open source technology and public space led to him forming the [[Graffiti Research Lab]] ("GRL") with [[James Powderly]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite news | last = Quinlan | first = Adriane | title = How Graffiti Artists are Cleaning Up | pages = | publisher = [[Time Magazine]] | date = 2007-12-06 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1691618,00.html | accessdate = 2008-11-19 }} </ref> GRL projects include [[LED Throwies]] and [[L.A.S.E.R. Tag]]. In 2007, Roth co-founded the [[Free Art and Technology Lab]] (F.A.T. Lab), an Internet-based art-and-technology collective dedicated to the intersection of open-source hacking and popular culture. He has worked under the pseudonym ''fi5e''.<ref>http://www.sciarc.edu/lectures.php?id=1357</ref>
Roth and Ben Engebreth were awarded a 2007 Rhizome Commission for White Glove Tracking, which was presented at the Contemporary New Museum in New York City.<ref>[http://www.whiteglovetracking.com whiteglovetracking.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.rhizome.org/commissions/2007/ Rhizome|2007 Commissions]</ref> Roth was again awarded a Rhizome Commission in 2008 for his project "T.S.A. Communications." <ref>[http://www.rhizome.org/commissions/2009/ Rhizome|2009 Commissions]</ref>
Several of Roth's work are in the permanent collection of the [[Museum of Modern Art]].<ref>http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=33190</ref> Roth currently{{when|date=April 2014}} lives in Paris with his wife.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}

The '''flexible path''' was a set of destinations for further [[human spaceflight|crewed]] [[space exploration]] in the [[inner Solar System]] proposed in the [[Review of United States Human Space Flight Plans Committee]] of 2009 and was envisioned as alternative to the [[Moon]]-first and [[Mars]]-first approaches.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} In 2010 president [[Barack Obama]] announced [[Barack Obama space policy speech at Kennedy Space Center|change in the space policy]] from the Moon-first approach (adopted previously under the [[Vision for Space Exploration]] and [[Constellation program]]) to a variety of destinations resembling{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} the flexible path approach. == Outer space exploration destinations envisioned in [[Space policy of the United States|US space policy]] == '''Bold''' designates missions beyond [[Cis-lunar space]].
'''Legend
'   [flyby] — [orbit] — [landing] Current as of 2010:{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} * [[sub-orbital flight]]s * [[Low Earth Orbit]] - the [[International Space Station]] ''([[Project Constellation#International Space Station and low-Earth orbit flights|Constellation program]] initial destination'') ''Flexible path'' beyond Low Earth Orbit:{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} * [[Moon]] [[Planetary flyby|flyby]] or orbit - for testing and development purposes * Earth-Moon [[Lagrangian point|L1]] - [[Space rendezvous|assembly]] complex for other missions, servicing of [[propellant depot]]s or other spacecraft such as self-propulsion observatories and reusable non-[[Atmospheric reentry|reentry]] crew or cargo vehicles * '''Earth-Sun [[Lagrangian point|L2]]''' - servicing of [[Space observatory|space observatories]] requiring Earth shade * '''Earth-Sun [[Lagrangian point|L1]]''' - servicing of [[Solar observatory|solar observatories]] or manned solar observatory ''([[Apollo Telescope Mount|similar to proposal]] for the [[Apollo Applications Program]])'' * '''[[Near-Earth object]]s''' ''([[Project Constellation#Orion asteroid mission|Constellation program]] third destination'') * '''[[Mars]]''' [[Planetary flyby|flyby]] * [[Moon landing]] ''([[Project Constellation#Lunar sortie/outpost flights|Constellation program]] second destination)'' * '''[[Mars]]''' orbit, including robotic landing and [[sample return]] * '''[[Mars Moons]]''' * '''[[Venus]]''' [[Planetary flyby|flyby]] or orbit [http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/396093main_HSF_Cmte_FinalReport.pdf HSF Final Report: Seeking a Human Spaceflight Program Worthy of a Great Nation], October 2009, ''Review of U.S. Human Spaceflight Plans Committee'', p. 40. ''([[Manned Venus Flyby|similar to proposal]] for the [[Apollo Applications Program]])'' * '''[[Mars landing]]''' ''([[Project Constellation#Orion Mars mission|Constellation program]] final destination)'' The list is ordered according to the [[delta-v]] required by the mission. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Spaceflight concepts]] [[Category:2010 in American politics]] [[Category:2010 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Human spaceflight]] [[Category:Constellation program]] [[Category:Discovery and exploration of the Solar System]] [[Category:Space policy of the United States]]

{{Infobox person | name = Fouad Abdelmoumni | birth_date = 1958 | birth_place = [[Berkane]], [[Morocco]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = Moroccan | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = Economist, Activist | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = Transparency Maroc (Secretary General) | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = https://abdelmoumni.wordpress.com/ | footnotes = }} '''Fouad Abdelmoumni''', born in Berkane in 1958, is a human rights activist and Moroccan economist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/110024/archives-thematique/fouad-abdelmoumni/|title=Fouad Abdelmoumni - JeuneAfrique.com|date=13 September 2004|publisher=}}</ref> He is the current secretary-general of [[Transparency Maroc]] since 13 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffpostmaghreb.com/2016/02/13/fouad-abdelmoumn-transparency-maroc_n_9226670.html|title=Fouad Abdelmoumni, nouveau secrétaire général de Transparency Maroc|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leconomiste.com/flash-infos/fouad-abdelmoumni-prend-la-tete-de-transparency-maroc|title=Fouad Abdelmoumni prend la tête de Transparency Maroc|date=13 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Also known for his actions in the field of microcredit, he was Director General of the NGO Al Amana from 1997 to 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lavieeco.com/news/portraits/passionne-du-microcredit-et-fondateur-de-la-plus-grande-association-al-amana-3248.html|title=Passionné du microcrédit et fondateur de la plus grande association, Al Amana|publisher=}}</ref>
==Early life== Fouad Abdelmoumni was born in 1958 in Berkane in the north-east of Morocco after the independence of 1956. His father, of Oujdie origin, is an official in the Ministry of Justice and will, because of his activism within the 'UNFP, subject to several mutations across the country during his career.
Fouad will thus find himself a pupil in a primary school in Fez and will continue his training at the lycée Moulay Idriss and then in Casablanca to complete his secondary studies in Ibn Toumert and Mohammed V. After obtaining in 1976 a bac in experimental sciences, he Is registered at the Institute of Agricultural and Veterinary Studies of Rabat.
==Early human rights activism== Since his 14 years old, he joined the national union of lycées in a clandestine activity. Regarding his political activism, he said, "At the time, in my milieu, one was necessarily republican and revolutionary. Or, it was necessary to accept to remain in withdrawal. ". During his academic year, while the country was in full conflict in the Sahara, and Hassan II, following the green march, confirmed his power and violently repressed his opponents, he was imprisoned for three years.

{{hatnote|This article serves as an overview of the topic. For more specific articles and other uses, see [[Freedom (disambiguation)]].}} '''Freedom''', generally, is having an ability to act or change without constraint. A thing is "free" if it can change its state easily and is not constrained in its present state. In philosophy and religion, it is associated with having [[free will]] and being without undue or unjust constraints, or [[slavery|enslavement]], and is an idea closely related to the concept of [[liberty]]. A person has the freedom to do things that will not, in theory or in practice, be prevented by other forces. Outside of the human realm, freedom generally does not have this political or psychological dimension. A rusty lock might be oiled so that the key has freedom to turn, undergrowth may be hacked away to give a newly planted sapling freedom to grow, or a mathematician may study an equation having many degrees of freedom. In mechanical engineering, "freedom" describes the number of independent motions that are allowed to a body or system, which is generally referred to as [[degrees of freedom]]."
==Free will== {{Main|Free will}} In philosophical discourse, freedom is discussed in the context of [[free will]] and self-determination, balanced by [[moral responsibility]].
Advocates of free will regard freedom of thought as innate to the human mind, while opponents regard the mind as thinking only the thoughts that a purely deterministic brain happens to be engaged in at the time.
==Social freedom or liberty== [[File:OURS TO FIGHT FOR. 4 FREEDOMS ON ONE SHEET - NARA - 513635.jpg|thumb|right|[[Four Freedoms]], a series of paintings meant to describe the freedoms for which allied nations fought in World War II.]] {{Main|Political freedom|Liberty}} In political discourse, [[political freedom]] is often associated with [[liberty]] and [[autonomy]] in the sense of "giving oneself one's own laws", and with having [[rights]] and the [[civil liberties]] with which to exercise them without undue interference by the state. Frequently discussed kinds of political freedom include [[freedom of assembly]], [[freedom of association]], [[freedom of choice]], and [[freedom of speech]].
In some circumstances, particularly when discussion is limited to political freedoms, the terms "freedom" and "liberty" tend to be used interchangeably.<ref>''See'' Bertrand Badie, Dirk Berg-Schlosser, Leonardo Morlino, ''International Encyclopedia of Political Science'' (2011), p. 1447: "Throughout this entry, incidentally, the terms freedom and liberty are used interchangeably".</ref><ref name="Wierzbicka">Anna Wierzbicka, ''Understanding Cultures Through Their Key Words'' (1997), p. 130-31: "Unfortunately... the English words freedom and liberty are used interchangeably. This is confusing because these two do not mean the same, and in fact what [Isaiah] Berlin calls "the notion of 'negative' freedom" has become largely incorporated in the word ''freedom'', whereas the word ''liberty'' in its earlier meaning was much closer to the Latin libertas and in its current meaning reflects a different concept, which is a product of the Anglo-Saxon culture".</ref> Elsewhere, however, subtle distinctions between freedom and liberty have been noted.<ref>Wendy Hui Kyong Chun, ''Control and Freedom: Power and Paranoia in the Age of Fiber Optics'' (2008), p. 9: "Although used interchangeably, freedom and liberty have significantly different etymologies and histories. According to the ''Oxford English Dictionary'', the Old English ''frei'' (derived from Sanskrit) meant dear and described all those close or related to the head of the family (hence friends). Conversely in Latin, ''libertas'' denoted the legal state of being free versus enslaved and was later extended to children (''liberi''), meaning literally the free members of the household. Those who are one's friends are free; those who are not are slaves".</ref> [[John Stuart Mill]], differentiated liberty from freedom in that freedom is primarily, if not exclusively, the ability to do as one wills and what one has the power to do; whereas liberty concerns the absence of arbitrary restraints and takes into account the rights of all involved. As such, the exercise of liberty is subject to capability and limited by the rights of others.<ref name=mill1>Mill, J.S. (1869)., "Chapter I: Introductory", ''On Liberty''. http://www.bartleby.com/130/1.html</ref>
Wendy Hui Kyong Chun explains the differences in terms of their relation to institutions:
{{quote|''Liberty is linked to human subjectivity; freedom is not. The Declaration of Independence, for example, describes men as having liberty and the nation as being free. Free will—''the quality of being free from the control of fate or necessity''—may first have been attributed to human will, but [[Newtonian physics]] attributes freedom—[[degrees of freedom]], [[free bodies]]—to objects.''<ref name="Chun">Wendy Hui Kyong Chun, ''Control and Freedom: Power and Paranoia in the Age of Fiber Optics'' (2008), p. 9.</ref>}}
{{quote|''Freedom differs from liberty as control differs from discipline. Liberty, like discipline, is linked to institutions and political parties, whether liberal or libertarian; freedom is not. Although freedom can work for or against institutions, it is not bound to them—it travels through unofficial networks. To have liberty is to be liberated from something; to be free is to be self-determining, autonomous. Freedom can or cannot exist within a state of liberty: one can be liberated yet ''unfree,'' or ''free'' yet enslaved (Orlando Patterson has argued in ''Freedom: Freedom in the Making of Western Culture'' that freedom arose from the yearnings of slaves).''<ref name="Chun"/>}}
Another distinction that some political theorists have deemed important is that people may aspire to have freedom ''from'' limiting forces (such as [[freedom from fear]], [[freedom from want]], and [[freedom from discrimination]]), but descriptions of freedom and liberty generally do not invoke having liberty ''from'' anything.<ref name="Wierzbicka"/> To the contrary, the concept of [[negative liberty]] refers to the liberty one person may have to restrict the rights of others.<ref name="Wierzbicka"/>
Other important fields in which freedom is an issue include [[economic freedom]], [[academic freedom]], [[intellectual freedom]], and [[scientific freedom]].
==Freedom as a physical concept== In purely physical terms, freedom is used much more broadly to describe the limits to which physical movement or other physical processes are possible. This relates to the philosophical concept to the extent that people may be considered to have as much freedom as they are physically able to exercise. The number of independent [[variable (mathematics)|variables]] or parameters for a system is described as its number of [[degrees of freedom]]. For example the movement of a vehicle along a road has two degrees of freedom; to go fast or slow, or to change direction by turning left or right. The movement of a ship sailing on the waves has four degrees of freedom, since it can also pitch nose-to-tail and roll side-to-side. An aeroplane can also climb and sideslip, giving it [[six degrees of freedom]].
[[Degrees of freedom (mechanics)|Degrees of freedom in mechanics]] describes the number of independent motions that are allowed to a body, or, in case of a [[Mechanism (engineering)|mechanism]] made of several bodies, the number of possible independent relative motions between the pieces of the mechanism. In the study of complex [[motor control]], there may be so many degrees of freedom that a given action can be achieved in different ways by combining movements with different degrees of freedom. This issue is sometimes called the [[degrees of freedom problem]].
==Freedom in mathematical theory== In [[mathematics]] freedom is the ability of a [[variable (mathematics)|variable]] to change in value.
Some equations have many such variables. This notion is formalized as the [[dimension (mathematics and physics)|dimension]] of a [[manifold]] or an [[algebraic variety]]. When ''degrees of freedom'' is used instead of ''dimension'', this usually means that the manifold or variety that models the system is only implicitly defined. Such degrees of freedom appear in many mathematical and related disciplines, including [[Degrees of freedom (physics and chemistry)|degrees of freedom]] as used in [[physics]] and [[chemistry]] to explain dependence on [[parameter]]s, or the [[dimensions]] of a [[phase space]]; and [[Degrees of freedom (statistics)|degrees of freedom in statistics]], the number of values in the final calculation of a [[statistic]] that are free to vary.
